utterances: Good afternoon.
About - I've been married for almost two years.
Me and my wife - her wedding dress came up in two parts, a corset top and then the main flowing train it's got for the bottom.
Well, she waited a year after we were married, went on a photo shoot, because she used to be a model, did the photo shoot and then just for shoots and giggles, oh, pardon my frank…
All right.
Let's try that again.
She went through and did the photo shoot.

And then through a (inaudible) through, she took part of the bottom off and did, like, a little flame job with an actual - not a blow torch but like a little butane lighter-type thing at the end of train and the start of what she would call, the ball and chain.
And she kept the corset part as - to go on for the rest of the photo shoot.
Sounds interesting.
I'd like to see that.
All right.
That would be interesting, Karl.
Thanks very much for the call.
Thanks a lot.
You, guys have a good day.
All right.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can get - this is Steve(ph) on the line.
Steve with us from Columbus, Ohio.
Yes, sir.
That's me.
Yeah.
Go ahead.
You're on the air.

Oh, I was just calling to tell you, I was actually trying to get in about the first half ago, but we actually did some interesting (unintelligible) stuff going on with the dress on the - a little bit after the wedding.
After the wedding, it has become a tradition with my friends where we all go out to some dirty, little dive bar, the - probably the worst one that we can find in the town of the wedding.
So we find this little bar, it's only actually - it ends up being about 10 feet from the hotel.
We went out to the bar.
My wife only actually wanted to be there for just a short while.
We ended up being there for about two hours or so having a good time.
We get back to the hotel room afterwards, and you know, going to get her, you know, out of her dress, which she, you know, been sweating like crazy in all day.

Get in there and there's actually about two inches of black ring, just gunk, you know, attached to the bottom of the dress all the way around it, which luckily, you know, they were able to get cleaned out of there, and the dress is now preserved and beautiful.
But we were amazed when we got back to the hotel room.
Yeah.
I suspect you may have run into a few stains, Mark Eric?
Actually, no. They got absolutely everything out of it.
The dress is beautiful, gorgeous now, completely preserved.
And there's nothing wrong with it.
But that night, man, we didn't think there was any way we were going to get that thing cleaned.
All right.
Thanks very much for the call, Steve.
Thank you, sir.
And dry cleaning, I suspect, is important in your business, Mark Eric.
It's been crazy.
This past week, I've had two e-mails from some national cleaning organization wanting to hook up with the dresses, so…
See if you could recommend them, maybe a little testimonial.
One of the - if I have a second, one of the funniest stories from last week, we did the bride in the swamp, which I see is featured on your website right now.
Yeah.
That dress washed(ph) clean right away.
The only stain she had was from leaning up against the pine tree in some of the sap got on the back on her dress.
After being in a murky bayous of Louisiana, the dress washed clean, they cut out some of the undernetting and she is going to put it up to serve(ph) future generations.
Mark Eric, thanks very much.
And have a good time this dizzy part of the year for you.
Thank you, sir.
Mark Eric is a wedding photographer.
He joined us from his office in Alexandria, Louisiana.
And if you'd like to see the picture of that dress he mentioned, there's a link at npr.org/blogofthenation.
When we return, we'll turn to the latest in the Middle East.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.

In Miami yesterday, federal air marshals open fired on a passenger who was acting erratically, a man they say claimed to have a bomb and then bolted down the aisle of the plane and out onto the jetway that connected the aircraft to the terminal.
A spokesman for the federal air marshals said that Rigoberto Alpizar refused to obey commands to stop, and when he reached into his backpack, he was shot and killed by two air marshals.
Beth, that's a really fair question.
I think, by and large, that you'll find that force protection is a real concern for General Odierno and whoever succeeds him in the job.
I'm not quite as concerned about force protection for American troops, but this is going to be a difficult time for the Iraqi military and their security forces simply because they are on their own.
They're standing up, and we can only hope that they're - they - that we prepared them well enough to do the job in the future.
Yes, sir.
Hopefully, they can really learn a lot from the remaining soldiers.
And hopefully - unfortunately, there's not a - no osmosis is possible.

But I'm just concerned, then, that they're going to be taking on the role of protecting, basically, or, you know, being the same as the 50,000 troops that are there and kind of acting as their protectors.
And that was my question, sir.
Thanks for the call, Beth.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Bye-bye.

There's the question she asked about the Iraqi army, essentially, but there's also the police who have been, in the past - back in the bad, old days of the near civil war there - infected by a lot of sectarian forces.
That's always a concern.
I think there's - there have been a lot of improvements.
The - I can only speak for the northwest Baghdad and Abu Ghraib area, where I was.
But I saw a great deal of improvement in the year that I was there.
Now I've been gone since February, but I'm fairly confident that they're on an upward trajectory.
Let's get another caller in.
This is Dave, Dave with us from Miami.
Good afternoon, Neal.
How are you?
I'm well.
Thank you.
I'm a long-time listener, first-time caller.
Well, thank you.
I served in Vietnam.
That was my war.
And I did a lot of the type of fighting that they have done recently in the area we are committed in - both areas that we are committed in now.
I have been watching the situation very closely because I do have concern for my military.

And I feel that when we look at the legislature that was elected sometime ago, and they have not formed a government a yet, I feel that the level of disintegration that is within that country, we would do well to get the hell out of there as fast as we can, because they don't want us there.
When we were in Korea, as we still are, we never heard people saying that we are the cause of the problem, as I have heard in reports from Baghdad over time.
And it seems as if whatever goes wrong, we're the guys that's responsible, but we're really not going to be making any decisions.
So I think the best thing to do is move out and go home.
Colonel Anderson - just Dave, I do remember phases of anti-American demonstrations in Korean back in the '60s, and subsequent, hundreds of thousands of people demonstrating against U.S.
forces.
But, anyway...
Well, I think the problem you run in here - to here is, you know, one of complexity.

But I'll be honest with you, I think after the amount of time we spent in Iraq, you're going to find that there are a lot of Iraqis who are really, really worried about us just totally up and leaving.

You know, there's always going to be a certain amount of, you know, anti-foreign sentiment and so forth, but I - but I'll tell you, I heard an awful lot more in the way of we really wish you guys would stay around a little bit longer than I did get out of our country.
Well, I understand what you're saying, and I don't mean that we should be preemptively about the exit.
We've got to do it with decorum, obviously.
But the point is we shouldn't be looking to prolong our presence in that particular environment, because we are dealing with a totally different mentality.
Dave, the current agreement with the Iraqi government calls for all U.S.
forces to be out by the end of next year, the end of 2011.
Is that a timetable that seems to work?
Sounds good to me.
All right, Dave.
Thanks very much.
And thank you.
